intro: Lamprotis gnaphalodes, commonly known as the golden ragwort, is a flowering plant native to North America. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is characterized by its yellow-orange flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as fields and roadsides. It has hairy, lance-shaped leaves and produces a milky sap that can be toxic to livestock. Lamprotis gnaphalodes plays a role in supporting pollinators like bees and butterflies.
